title: A Look Back: My Migraine Journey in 2023

content: Well, we all blinked, and another calendar year has passed us by.

We all collectively prayed as a football player had a heart attack during the middle of a game and as a Chinese spy balloon haunted us all. We grieved as some of our faves left us – from Tina Turner and Bob Barker to the amazing Rosalynn Carter. I didn’t expect the death of Pee-wee Herman (Paul Reubens) to affect me, but it did. It’s like a piece of my childhood died. I got his humor.
I celebrated Ken and Barbie (appreciating the diversity of the movie), agonized over outfits for the Beyonce concert, and binged on HBO’s Succession.

As the events of the world continued to tick by, I was in my little world continuing to navigate my 30-year history with migraine. You’d think after this long I would be familiar with it fully. Yet, I’m still learning, still growing. I was fortunate enough to participate in a special migraine video series and I finally gave my mom her flowers as someone who helped me in my early migraine days. I learned what she endured as a migraine warrior long before the advancements we have today.

We grieved as some of our faves left us – from Tina Turner and Bob Barker to the amazing Rosalynn Carter. I didn’t expect the death of Pee-wee Herman (Paul Reubens) to affect me, but it did. As the events of the world continued to tick by, I was in my little world continuing to navigate my 30-year history with migraine. You’d think after this long I would be familiar with it fully. Yet, I’m still learning, still growing. I was fortunate enough to participate in a special migraine video series and I finally gave my mom her flowers as someone who helped me in my early migraine days. I learned what she endured as a migraine warrior long before the advancements we have today.

content: These are the things I learned this year about my migraines that I hope to carry with me in the years to come.

Migraines today look different than they did years ago. I mean, I assumed this, but nothing drove this home as much as talking to my mother about her experiences with them growing up in the ’50s. I took for granted all the advancements in migraine research and the treatments available today. If you grew up with migraine before the ’80s – I salute you!

The news is full these days with reports of racism in the medical community. It’s what many people of color already knew. As I reflected on my years with migraine, it was both painful and healing to think about the moments in life where I felt gaslighted, ignored, or humiliated simply because of the color of my skin. If my story can help others feel heard and seen and perhaps, as a result, get a diagnosis and proper treatment, then I’ll continue to vulnerably share my story.

As I reflected on my years with migraine, it was both painful and healing to think about the moments in life where I felt gaslighted, ignored, or humiliated simply because of the color of my skin. If my story can help others feel heard and seen and perhaps, as a result, get a diagnosis and proper treatment, then I’ll continue to vulnerably share my story.

sections.heading: I am not the only one.
content: Having migraines can make you a bit selfish – because you have to be. Also, no one wears a sign around their neck that reads: “Having a migraine.” (Hmmmm … T-shirt idea?) I’ve felt lonely with my migraine episodes, and other than a handful of friends and family with them, I haven’t really noticed many others in my life with them. But I started paying attention. Mindfulness takes many forms. I started not only paying attention to my own health and self-care, but I tuned my ears to others when they mentioned they had a migraine. If I wasn’t having one myself, I tried to extend compassion and grace. It takes a village to raise a child. It takes an army to fight a migraine.
I am sustained by my faith.

For whatever reason, I haven’t always brought my “little” prayers to God. I have been consistent in praying about things in my life and seeking the Lord for other people. A few years ago, I started sending up what some might call small prayers. Although migraine has been a big part of my life, I haven’t always seen it as worthy of prayer. I was resolved to just live with the episodes, and that’s it. I’ve noticed as I’ve started praying about pain relief, connection to resources, or awareness about how to improve my overall health that God has listened.  I guess that’s how prayer works.

sections.heading: I am more than a migraine.
content: Migraine, like most chronic illnesses, can be all-consuming. I spend my days working hard to prevent them or trying to recover from them. I know everyone says they are more than their [insert illness], but it’s become super real for me lately. As I round the halftime of my life (in my 40s), I’m doing quite a bit of soul-seeking.

People talk about midlife crisis for men as they purchase new sports cars, but I think all genders go through this and sometimes more than once in their lives. I dedicated several months this year to going on a little self-discovery.  I was reminded that I love to travel for pleasure (not just business). I was reinvigorated as a writer and started calling myself one in public. I do have migraine, but I’m also a million other little things. So are you.
